page.title: 02Gayton Village
page.content: The village of Gayton is perched on the brow of a hill overlooking Northampton. The hill is the highest point in south Northamptonshire. In fact, eastwards there is not a higher elevation until the Russian Steppes. The village, which is surrounded by fields containing cereal crops and dairy grazing can be entered by one of five roads from the North, South, East, South-East and West illustrating its importance as a focal point to the community in the past, most likely a manorial centre. The roads meet at a point in the village called "Five Ways". The original manor house had direct access to the church which dates from the twelth century. The latter still contains a smaller door facing the present manor house.
